newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila looks for money to cover oil buffer fund.
newsitem.headline: Manila looks for money to cover oil buffer fund.

text.p: The Philippines is looking for funds to cover the deficit in its Oil Price Stabilisation Fund (OPSF), finance secretary Roberto de Ocampo said on Tuesday.

In a report to President Fidel Ramos, de Ocampo said the government should start paying the deficit which currently stands at about 2.0 billion pesos, and warned that it might grow to 2.3 billion pesos by the end of the year.

The OPSF is a mechanism introduced in the 1980s where oil companies contributed a portion of their earnings when prices of fuel oil were cheap in the international market and when the peso was strong against the U.S. dollar. They drew money from the buffer fund when the situation changed.
The fund started incurring a deficit last year when prices of fuel oil remained high in the world market.
Oil companies have been asking the government to cover the deficits.
De Ocampo said the government's inability to settle the issue will set a bad precedent in financial markets.

De Ocampo suggested the use of the proceeds from a recent Brady bond exchange, apportioning a part of the revenue from a comprehensive tax reform package, or using the proceeds from the sale of some energy-related state corporations.
President Ramos has yet to give his final decision on the matter. -- Manila newsroom +63 2 8418938 Fax +63 2 8176267
